Sorry Seems to be the Hardest Word.term: Sorry Seems to be the Hardest Word
Sorry Seems to be the Hardest Word.passage: "Sorry Seems to be the Hardest Word" is a song written by Elton John and Bernie Taupin. It was released in 1976 as a single from John's album "Blue Moves". The song is a ballad that features John's piano and vocals, accompanied by a string section and a choir. The lyrics of the song deal with the difficulty of apologizing and admitting fault in a relationship. The chorus repeats the phrase "sorry seems to be the hardest word" as John laments the pain caused by his inability to express remorse. The song's emotional depth and vulnerability have made it a popular choice for cover versions and have cemented its place as one of John's most enduring hits. "Sorry Seems to be the Hardest Word" was a commercial success, reaching the top 20 in several countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, and Canada. It has been covered by numerous artists, including Joe Cocker, Mary J. Blige, and Blue. The song has also been featured in several films and television shows, including "The Devil Wears Prada" and "The Sopranos". The song's success can be attributed to its universal theme of regret and the difficulty of admitting fault. John's emotive vocals and the song's simple yet powerful melody have made it a timeless classic that continues to resonate with audiences today.

Stairway to Heaven.passage: Stairway to Heaven is a song by the English rock band Led Zeppelin, released in 1971. It was composed by guitarist Jimmy Page and vocalist Robert Plant for the band's fourth studio album, Led Zeppelin IV. The song is often considered one of the greatest rock songs of all time and has become a staple of classic rock radio. Stairway to Heaven is a progressive rock song that features a slow, acoustic guitar intro that gradually builds in intensity and complexity. The song's lyrics are mystical and poetic, drawing on themes of spirituality, mythology, and the afterlife. The song's title is a reference to the biblical story of Jacob's ladder, which describes a stairway that reaches from Earth to Heaven. The song's iconic guitar solo, played by Jimmy Page, is widely regarded as one of the greatest guitar solos in rock history. The solo features a series of intricate and melodic runs that showcase Page's technical skill and musicality. The solo builds to a climax with a series of soaring notes that perfectly capture the song's sense of transcendence and spiritual elevation. Stairway to Heaven has been covered by numerous artists and has been featured in countless films, TV shows, and commercials. The song's enduring popularity is a testament to its timeless appeal and its ability to resonate with listeners across generations. Despite its popularity, Stairway to Heaven has also been the subject of controversy. In 2016, the song was at the center of a high-profile copyright infringement lawsuit, in which the estate of Randy California, the late guitarist of the band Spirit, claimed that Led Zeppelin had plagiarized the opening chords of Stairway to Heaven from Spirit's song "Taurus." The lawsuit was ultimately dismissed, but it sparked a debate about the boundaries of copyright law and the ethics of borrowing from other artists. Regardless of its legal controversies, Stairway to Heaven remains a beloved and iconic song that continues to inspire and captivate listeners around the world.

Bohemian Rhapsody.passage: Bohemian Rhapsody is a song by the British rock band Queen. It was written by Freddie Mercury for the band's 1975 album A Night at the Opera. The song is a six-minute suite, consisting of several sections without a chorus: an intro, a ballad segment, an operatic passage, a hard rock part and a reflective coda. The song is a complex and intricate piece of music, featuring layered vocals, multiple guitar parts, and a wide range of musical styles. Bohemian Rhapsody was a commercial and critical success upon its release, reaching number one in the UK charts and becoming one of Queen's most popular songs. It has since become a cultural phenomenon, with its iconic opening piano chords and memorable lyrics being recognized around the world. The song's lyrics are famously enigmatic, with Mercury himself describing them as "just a bunch of random rhyming nonsense". However, many interpretations have been suggested over the years, with some seeing the song as a reflection on Mercury's personal life, while others see it as a commentary on the state of the world at the time. The song's operatic section, featuring Mercury's multi-tracked vocals, has become one of the most famous moments in rock music history. The section was inspired by Mercury's love of opera, and features a pastiche of different styles, including Italian opera, English balladry, and even a brief nod to the Beach Boys. Bohemian Rhapsody has been covered and parodied countless times over the years, and has been used in numerous films, TV shows, and commercials. It was also the inspiration for the title of the 2018 biopic about Mercury and Queen, which went on to become a box office success and win several awards. Despite its age, Bohemian Rhapsody remains a beloved and iconic song, and is widely regarded as one of the greatest pieces of music ever recorded. Its enduring popularity is a testament to the talent and creativity of Freddie Mercury and the rest of Queen, and their ability to create music that transcends time and genre.

Hotel California.passage: Hotel California is a song by the American rock band Eagles. It was released in February 1977 as the lead single from their album of the same name. Written by Don Felder, Don Henley, and Glenn Frey, the song is considered one of the greatest rock songs of all time. It has been covered by numerous artists and has been featured in several films and television shows. The song's lyrics describe a surreal and mysterious hotel that is seemingly impossible to leave. The hotel is described as luxurious and opulent, but also dark and ominous. The lyrics are open to interpretation, with many fans and critics speculating that the song is about drug addiction, the music industry, or even purgatory. Musically, Hotel California is known for its iconic guitar solo, which was performed by Don Felder. The song also features intricate harmonies and a haunting melody. It was a commercial success, reaching number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and winning the Grammy Award for Record of the Year in 1978. Despite its popularity, the song has also been the subject of controversy. Some religious groups have accused the song of promoting Satanism, while others have criticized its alleged glorification of drug use. The Eagles have denied these claims, stating that the song is simply a work of fiction. In addition to its musical legacy, Hotel California has also become a cultural icon. The phrase "Hotel California" has been used to describe anything from a real hotel in Mexico to a metaphor for the American Dream. The song has been referenced in numerous films, television shows, and books, and has been covered by artists ranging from Gipsy Kings to Frank Ocean. Overall, Hotel California remains one of the Eagles' most enduring and beloved songs. Its timeless lyrics and unforgettable melody continue to captivate audiences around the world, cementing its place in rock and roll history.

Sweet Caroline.passage: "Sweet Caroline" is a song written and performed by American singer-songwriter Neil Diamond. It was released in 1969 as a single from his album "Brother Love's Travelling Salvation Show". The song has become one of Diamond's most popular and enduring hits, and has been covered by numerous artists over the years. The song's origins are somewhat shrouded in mystery. Diamond has said that he was inspired to write the song after seeing a photo of Caroline Kennedy, daughter of President John F. Kennedy, in a magazine. However, he has also said that the song was actually written about his then-wife, Marcia Murphey. Regardless of its inspiration, "Sweet Caroline" has become a beloved classic, and is often played at sporting events, weddings, and other celebrations. The song's catchy melody and sing-along chorus have made it a favorite of fans around the world. The opening lines, "Where it began, I can't begin to knowin'/But then I know it's growing strong," have become iconic, and the chorus of "Sweet Caroline, ba ba ba/Good times never seemed so good" is instantly recognizable. Over the years, "Sweet Caroline" has been covered by a wide range of artists, including Elvis Presley, Frank Sinatra, and Roy Orbison. It has also been used in numerous films and TV shows, including "Breaking Bad" and "The Office". In 2013, following the Boston Marathon bombing, the song became an unofficial anthem for the city of Boston, and was played at sporting events and other public gatherings as a show of solidarity and support. Despite its enduring popularity, "Sweet Caroline" has also been the subject of some controversy. In recent years, some have criticized the song's lyrics, particularly the line "touching me, touching you," as being inappropriate in the wake of the #MeToo movement.

Thriller.passage: Thriller is the sixth studio album by American singer Michael Jackson, released on November 30, 1982. It is considered one of the greatest albums of all time and is Jackson's best-selling album, with over 66 million copies sold worldwide. The album was produced by Quincy Jones and features collaborations with Paul McCartney, Eddie Van Halen, and Vincent Price. Thriller features nine tracks, including the hit singles "Billie Jean," "Beat It," and the title track "Thriller." The album's sound is a fusion of pop, rock, funk, and R&B, with Jackson's signature vocal style and dance moves. The album's lyrics explore themes of love, relationships, and social issues. The album's success was due in part to its groundbreaking music videos, which were directed by John Landis and featured elaborate choreography and special effects. The video for "Thriller" is considered one of the greatest music videos of all time and helped to popularize the concept of the music video as an art form. Thriller received critical acclaim upon its release and won eight Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year. It has been included on numerous "best of" lists and has been cited as a major influence on contemporary pop music. The album's success also helped to establish Jackson as a global superstar and cemented his status as the "King of Pop." Despite its success, Thriller has been the subject of controversy in recent years due to allegations of child sexual abuse against Jackson. The allegations have led some fans and critics to reevaluate the album's legacy and its impact on popular culture. However, Thriller remains a landmark album in the history of popular music and a testament to Jackson's talent and influence.

Imagine.passage: Imagine is a song written and performed by English musician John Lennon. It was released as a single in 1971 and later appeared on his album of the same name. The song is widely regarded as one of Lennon's greatest works and has become an anthem for peace and unity. The lyrics of Imagine are simple yet powerful, calling for a world without borders, religion, or possessions. Lennon's vision of a utopian society where people live in harmony has resonated with generations of listeners and has become a symbol of hope for a better future. The song's melody is equally iconic, with its gentle piano intro and soaring chorus. Lennon's vocals are raw and emotional, conveying the sincerity of his message. The song's production is sparse, with only a few instruments accompanying Lennon's voice, giving the song a sense of intimacy and vulnerability. Imagine has been covered by countless artists over the years, including Elton John, Madonna, and Lady Gaga. It has also been used in numerous films, TV shows, and commercials, cementing its place in popular culture. Despite its popularity, Imagine has also been the subject of controversy. Some have criticized the song for being too simplistic and unrealistic, while others have accused Lennon of being hypocritical for advocating for a world without possessions while living a lavish lifestyle. Regardless of its critics, Imagine remains a beloved and influential song that continues to inspire people around the world. Its message of peace and unity is as relevant today as it was when it was first released, and its legacy will undoubtedly endure for generations to come.

Billie Jean.passage: Billie Jean is a song by American singer Michael Jackson, released in 1983 as the second single from his sixth studio album, Thriller. It was written and composed by Jackson and produced by Quincy Jones and Jackson. The song's lyrics refer to a real-life experience of Jackson, in which a female fan claimed that he was the father of one of her twins. Jackson denied the claim and wrote the song as a response. The song became a worldwide hit, reaching number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and staying there for seven weeks. It also topped the charts in several other countries, including the United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia. The music video for the song, directed by Steve Barron, featured Jackson performing the song's iconic dance moves and was widely praised for its innovative use of special effects. Billie Jean has been widely regarded as one of Jackson's greatest songs and has been covered by numerous artists over the years. It has also been the subject of several controversies, including allegations of plagiarism and a lawsuit filed by a woman named Billie Jean Jones, who claimed that the song was about her. Despite the controversies, Billie Jean remains a beloved and iconic song in the history of popular music. Its catchy melody, memorable lyrics, and innovative music video have made it a timeless classic that continues to be enjoyed by fans around the world.

We Will Rock You.passage: We Will Rock You is a musical based on the songs of British rock band Queen with a book by Ben Elton. The musical tells the story of a group of Bohemians who struggle to restore the free exchange of thought, fashion, and live music in a distant future where everyone dresses, thinks and acts the same. Musical instruments and composers are forbidden, and rock music is all but unknown. The show opened in London's West End at the Dominion Theatre on May 14, 2002, with Tony Vincent, Hannah Jane Fox, and Sharon D. Clarke in principal roles. It was directed by Christopher Renshaw and choreographed by Arlene Phillips, with set design by Mark Fisher, lighting design by Willie Williams, and costume design by Tim Goodchild. The original production closed on May 31, 2014, after a 12-year run, making it the longest-running musical ever at the Dominion Theatre. We Will Rock You has since been produced in numerous countries around the world, including Australia, Canada, Germany, Japan, Spain, and the United States. The show has been translated into several languages, including Dutch, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, and Swedish. The musical features many of Queen's greatest hits, including "Bohemian Rhapsody," "We Will Rock You," "We Are the Champions," "Somebody to Love," "Radio Ga Ga," "I Want to Break Free," "Under Pressure," "Killer Queen," "Don't Stop Me Now," "Who Wants to Live Forever," and "The Show Must Go On." We Will Rock You has received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the show's energy and spectacle, while others have criticized its thin plot and reliance on nostalgia. Despite this, the show has been a commercial success, grossing over $1.4 billion worldwide and attracting over 16 million people to its various productions. In addition to the stage musical, We Will Rock You has also been adapted into a feature film, a video game, and a touring concert production featuring former Queen members Brian May and Roger Taylor. The show's enduring popularity has cemented Queen's place as one of the most iconic and influential bands in rock history.

I Will Always Love You.passage: "I Will Always Love You" is a song written and originally recorded in 1973 by American singer-songwriter Dolly Parton. The song achieved commercial success when it was recorded by Whitney Houston in 1992 for the soundtrack of the film The Bodyguard, becoming one of the best-selling singles of all time. Parton wrote the song as a farewell to her former singing partner and mentor, Porter Wagoner, after she decided to pursue a solo career. The original recording of the song was a country ballad featuring Parton's signature twang and acoustic guitar accompaniment. Houston's version of the song, produced by David Foster, was a pop ballad with a more polished sound and a powerful vocal performance by Houston. The song was released as the lead single from The Bodyguard soundtrack and quickly became a worldwide hit, topping the charts in multiple countries and winning numerous awards, including a Grammy Award for Record of the Year. "I Will Always Love You" has since become one of the most iconic and beloved songs of all time, with its emotional lyrics and soaring melody resonating with audiences across generations. The song has been covered by countless artists and has been featured in numerous films and television shows. Despite its success, Parton has stated that she was initially hesitant to allow Houston to record the song, as she was concerned that the pop arrangement would not do justice to the original country version. However, she ultimately gave her blessing and has expressed her admiration for Houston's rendition of the song. Overall, "I Will Always Love You" remains a timeless classic and a testament to the enduring power of great songwriting and vocal performance.

Don't Stop Believin'.passage: "Don't Stop Believin'" is a song by American rock band Journey, originally released as a single from their seventh studio album Escape (1981). It became a top 10 hit on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and has since become one of the most popular and recognizable songs of the 1980s. The song was written by Journey members Steve Perry, Jonathan Cain, and Neal Schon. Perry came up with the title and melody, while Cain and Schon contributed to the lyrics and music. The song's upbeat tempo and catchy chorus have made it a staple of classic rock radio and a popular choice for karaoke. "Don't Stop Believin'" has been featured in numerous films, TV shows, and commercials, including the final scene of the HBO series The Sopranos and the 2009 film adaptation of the musical Rock of Ages. It has also been covered by a variety of artists, including Glee, which helped to introduce the song to a new generation of fans. Despite its enduring popularity, "Don't Stop Believin'" was not an immediate success upon its release. It initially peaked at number 9 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and fell off the charts after just 12 weeks. However, the song's popularity continued to grow over time, and it has since become one of the most beloved and iconic songs of the 1980s. In 2009, "Don't Stop Believin'" was certified platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) for sales of over 1 million digital downloads. It has also been recognized as one of the greatest songs of all time by numerous publications, including Rolling Stone, which ranked it at number 46 on their list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time. Overall, "Don't Stop Believin'" remains a beloved and timeless classic that continues to inspire and uplift listeners around the world. Its message of hope and perseverance has resonated with generations of fans, making it one of the most enduring and iconic songs in the history of rock music.

Livin' on a Prayer.passage: "Livin' on a Prayer" is a song by American rock band Bon Jovi, released in 1986 as the second single from their third album, Slippery When Wet. Written by Jon Bon Jovi, Richie Sambora, and Desmond Child, the song is one of Bon Jovi's signature tracks and has become a classic rock anthem. The song tells the story of a young couple, Tommy and Gina, who are struggling to make ends meet. Tommy works on the docks while Gina works at a diner, and they dream of a better life. The chorus, "Oh, we're halfway there, oh, livin' on a prayer," has become one of the most recognizable in rock music. "Livin' on a Prayer" was a massive commercial success, reaching number one on the Billboard Hot 100 and staying there for four weeks. It also topped the charts in several other countries, including Canada, Australia, and the United Kingdom. The song's success helped propel Slippery When Wet to become one of the best-selling albums of the 1980s. The song's music video, directed by Wayne Isham, features the band performing in a small club while interspersed with footage of Tommy and Gina's struggles. The video helped to further popularize the song and cement its place in pop culture. Over the years, "Livin' on a Prayer" has been covered by numerous artists and has been featured in several films, TV shows, and commercials. It has also been used as a rallying cry at sporting events and political rallies. In 2018, Bon Jovi was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, with "Livin' on a Prayer" cited as one of their most iconic songs. The band continues to perform the song live, and it remains a fan favorite and a staple of classic rock radio.

Smells Like Teen Spirit.passage: "Smells Like Teen Spirit" is a song by American rock band Nirvana. It is the opening track and lead single from the band's second album, Nevermind (1991), released on DGC Records. The unexpected success of the song propelled Nevermind to the top of the charts at the start of 1992, an event often marked as the point where grunge entered the mainstream. "Smells Like Teen Spirit" was written by Kurt Cobain, Krist Novoselic, and Dave Grohl. The song's lyrics and accompanying music video, directed by Samuel Bayer, were intended as a parody of the mainstream music industry and its culture. The song's title is a reference to a deodorant marketed to teenagers, and the lyrics contain a mix of nonsensical phrases and social commentary. The song's distinctive opening riff, played by Novoselic on bass, has become one of the most recognizable in rock music history. The song's chorus, with Cobain's anguished vocals singing "Here we are now, entertain us," has been interpreted as a commentary on the apathy and boredom of Generation X. "Smells Like Teen Spirit" was a critical and commercial success, and has since been widely regarded as one of the greatest songs of all time. It has been covered by numerous artists, and has been featured in films, television shows, and video games. The song's impact on popular culture has been compared to that of the Beatles' "I Want to Hold Your Hand" and Elvis Presley's "Heartbreak Hotel." Despite its success, Cobain grew to resent the song's popularity and the attention it brought to the band. In a 1993 interview with Rolling Stone, he said, "I'm embarrassed by it now. It's a cliché. It's been beaten to death. It's been parodied."

Like a Rolling Stone.passage: "Like a Rolling Stone" is a song by American singer-songwriter Bob Dylan, released on July 20, 1965, by Columbia Records. Its confrontational lyrics originated in an extended piece of verse Dylan wrote in June 1965, when he returned exhausted from a grueling tour of England. Dylan distilled this draft into four verses and a chorus. "Like a Rolling Stone" was recorded a few weeks later as part of the sessions for the forthcoming album Highway 61 Revisited. During a difficult two-day preproduction, Dylan struggled to find the essence of the song, which was demoed without success in 3/4 time. A breakthrough was made when it was tried in a rock music format, and rookie session musician Al Kooper improvised the organ riff for which the track is known. However, Columbia Records was unhappy with both the song's length at over six minutes and its heavy electric sound, and was hesitant to release it. It was only when a month later a copy was leaked to a new popular music club and heard by influential DJs that the song was put out as a single. Although radio stations were reluctant to play such a long track, "Like a Rolling Stone" reached number two in the US charts and became a worldwide hit. Critics have described the track as revolutionary in its combination of different musical elements, the youthful, cynical sound of Dylan's voice, and the directness of the question "How does it feel?" "Like a Rolling Stone" transformed Dylan's career and is today considered one of the most influential compositions in postwar popular music. It has been covered by numerous artists, from The Rolling Stones to Jimi Hendrix to Green Day, and was ranked as the greatest song of all time by Rolling Stone magazine in 2004. In 2016, Dylan was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature "for having created new poetic expressions within the great American song tradition".

Hallelujah.passage: Hallelujah is a Hebrew word meaning "praise the Lord". It is commonly used in religious contexts, particularly in Jewish and Christian worship services. The word is often used as an exclamation of joy or thanksgiving, and is frequently sung or chanted in hymns and other religious songs. The origins of the word Hallelujah can be traced back to the Hebrew Bible, where it appears numerous times in the Book of Psalms. In these passages, the word is used as a call to worship or as an expression of praise and thanksgiving to God. The word is also used in the New Testament, particularly in the Book of Revelation, where it is used to describe the worship of God in heaven. Over time, the word Hallelujah has become a popular expression of joy and celebration in secular contexts as well. It has been used in music, literature, and other forms of art to express a range of emotions, from exuberant joy to solemn reverence. One of the most famous musical compositions featuring the word Hallelujah is the song of the same name by Leonard Cohen. Originally released in 1984, the song has since become a beloved classic, covered by countless artists and featured in numerous films and television shows. Despite its popularity, the meaning of the word Hallelujah remains deeply rooted in religious tradition. It continues to be used as a powerful expression of faith and devotion, and as a reminder of the enduring power of praise and worship.

My Heart Will Go On.passage: "My Heart Will Go On" is a song recorded by Canadian singer Celine Dion. It serves as the main theme song to the 1997 blockbuster film Titanic, directed by James Cameron. The song was written by James Horner and Will Jennings, and produced by Horner and Walter Afanasieff. It was released on December 8, 1997, by Columbia Records as the lead single from the Titanic soundtrack album. "My Heart Will Go On" is a power ballad that features Dion's signature vocals and a prominent use of the flute. The song's lyrics describe the enduring love between the film's two main characters, Jack and Rose, and how their love will continue even after Jack's death. The song's melody and lyrics have become iconic, and it has been covered by numerous artists and used in various media. The song was a massive commercial success, topping the charts in multiple countries, including the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom. It won the Academy Award for Best Original Song, as well as the Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song. It also won four Grammy Awards, including Song of the Year and Record of the Year. "My Heart Will Go On" has become one of the best-selling singles of all time, with estimated sales of over 20 million copies worldwide. It has also become one of Dion's signature songs, and she has performed it on numerous occasions, including at the 70th Academy Awards in 1998 and during her Las Vegas residency show, Celine. The song's success has also led to various parodies and references in popular culture, including in the animated television series Family Guy and the film Deadpool 2. It has also been used in various advertisements and television shows. Overall, "My Heart Will Go On" has become a cultural phenomenon and a beloved classic, and it continues to be a staple of pop culture and music history.

All About That Bass.passage: "All About That Bass" is a song by American singer-songwriter Meghan Trainor, released as the lead single from her debut studio album, Title (2015). The song was written by Trainor and Kevin Kadish, and was produced by Kadish. It was released on June 30, 2014, through Epic Records. The song is a pop and doo-wop track that celebrates body positivity and self-acceptance, with lyrics that encourage women to embrace their curves and love themselves regardless of their size. The song's title refers to the bass guitar, which is used prominently in the song's instrumentation. "All About That Bass" was a commercial success, topping the charts in several countries, including the United States, Canada, Australia, and the United Kingdom. It also received critical acclaim, with many praising its catchy melody and positive message. The song's music video, directed by Fatima Robinson, features Trainor and a group of dancers performing choreography in various colorful sets. The video has been viewed over 2.5 billion times on YouTube, making it one of the most-watched videos on the platform. "All About That Bass" has been covered and parodied by numerous artists and internet personalities, and has been used in various films, television shows, and commercials. The song's success helped launch Trainor's career, and she has since become a prominent figure in the pop music industry. Despite its popularity, "All About That Bass" has also faced criticism for its lyrics, which some have argued promote a narrow definition of body positivity that excludes certain body types. Trainor has addressed these criticisms, stating that the song was intended to be inclusive and that she supports all body types.

Hey Jude.passage: "Hey Jude" is a song by the English rock band the Beatles, written by Paul McCartney and credited to Lennon–McCartney. The ballad evolved from "Hey Jules", a song McCartney wrote to comfort John Lennon's son, Julian, during his parents' divorce. McCartney later said, "I started with the idea 'Hey Jules,' which was Julian, don't make it bad, take a sad song and make it better. Hey, try and deal with this terrible thing. I knew it was not going to be easy for him. I always feel sorry for kids in divorces ... I had the idea [for the song] by the time I got there. I changed it to 'Jude' because I thought that sounded a bit better." The song was released in August 1968 as the first single from the Beatles' record label Apple Records. More than seven minutes in length, it was at the time the longest single ever to top the British charts. It also spent nine weeks at number one in the United States, the longest for any Beatles single. "Hey Jude" tied the "all-time" record, at the time, for the longest run at the top of the US charts. The single has sold approximately eight million copies and is frequently included on professional critics' lists of the greatest songs of all time. In 2013, Billboard named it the 10th biggest song of all time. The song's arrangement was by George Martin and has been described as a "pop hymn". It features a single verse and a long coda, with the coda being repeated several times. The song was recorded during the sessions for the Beatles' self-titled double album, commonly known as "the White Album", but was not included on the album's original release. It was later released on the compilation album Hey Jude in 1970. McCartney performed "Hey Jude" several times with his post-Beatles band Wings. He also performed the song live with Elton John, at John's 1987 concert at Wembley Stadium, London, and with Bruce Springsteen, at the Hard Rock Calling festival in London in 2012. McCartney has also performed the song at several benefit concerts, including Live Aid in 1985, the Concert for New York City in 2001, and the One World: Together at Home concert in 2020.

Sweet Child O' Mine.passage: Sweet Child O' Mine is a song by American rock band Guns N' Roses, released in 1987 as the third single from their debut album, Appetite for Destruction. The song was written by lead guitarist Slash and was inspired by his girlfriend at the time, Erin Everly. It is considered one of the greatest rock songs of all time and is often cited as Guns N' Roses' signature song. The song's iconic opening riff, played by Slash, is instantly recognizable and has become one of the most famous guitar riffs in rock history. The song's lyrics, written by lead singer Axl Rose, are a tribute to Everly and express his love and devotion to her. Sweet Child O' Mine was a commercial success, reaching number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in the United States and becoming the band's first and only number one hit. It also reached the top 10 in several other countries, including the United Kingdom, Canada, and Australia. The song's music video, directed by Nigel Dick, features the band performing the song in a rehearsal space and includes footage of Rose and Everly together. The video received heavy rotation on MTV and helped to further popularize the song. In addition to its commercial success, Sweet Child O' Mine has received critical acclaim and has been included on numerous "best of" lists. It was ranked number 37 on Rolling Stone's list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time and was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame in 2015. The song has also been covered by numerous artists, including Sheryl Crow, Taken by Trees, and Luna. It has been featured in several films and television shows, including Step Brothers, The Wrestler, and Stranger Things. Overall, Sweet Child O' Mine is a timeless classic that has stood the test of time and continues to be a beloved rock anthem. Its memorable guitar riff, heartfelt lyrics, and powerful vocals have cemented its place in rock history and made it a favorite among fans and critics alike.

Let it Be.passage: Let It Be is the twelfth and final studio album by the English rock band the Beatles. It was released on 8 May 1970, almost a month after the group's break-up, in tandem with the motion picture of the same name. Like most of the band's previous releases, the album topped record charts in many countries, including both the US and the UK. However, it received mixed reviews from music critics and fans alike, with some praising its raw, stripped-down sound and others criticizing its lack of cohesion and production values. The album was recorded in early 1969, during a tumultuous period for the band. The Beatles had just completed their previous album, Abbey Road, and tensions were high between the members. The sessions for Let It Be were initially intended to be a return to the band's roots, with the group recording live in the studio and eschewing the elaborate production techniques of their recent albums. However, the sessions quickly became fraught with disagreements and arguments, with the band members often working separately and only coming together sporadically. The album's title track, "Let It Be," was one of the last songs recorded for the album and became one of the band's most iconic and enduring hits. The song was written by Paul McCartney and inspired by a dream he had in which his mother, who had died when he was a teenager, came to him and told him to "let it be." The song's gospel-inflected sound and uplifting message struck a chord with audiences and helped to cement the Beatles' place in the pantheon of rock and roll legends. Other notable tracks on the album include "Get Back," which was originally intended as a single but was later included on the album, and "The Long and Winding Road," which was heavily produced by Phil Spector and became a controversial point of contention between McCartney and the other members of the band. The album also includes several tracks that were recorded during the band's famous rooftop concert, which took place on the roof of their Apple Corps headquarters in London in January 1969. Despite its mixed reception, Let It Be remains a beloved and influential album in the Beatles' discography. Its raw, unpolished sound and emphasis on live performance helped to pave the way for the rise of punk rock and other DIY genres in the years to come. The album also serves as a poignant reminder of the band's final days together, and the tensions and conflicts that ultimately led to their break-up.

Uptown Funk.passage: "Uptown Funk" is a song by British record producer Mark Ronson featuring American singer and songwriter Bruno Mars. The song was released as the lead single from Ronson's fourth studio album, "Uptown Special," on November 10, 2014. It was written by Ronson, Mars, Jeff Bhasker, Philip Lawrence, and Devon Gallaspy, and produced by Ronson, Bhasker, and Mars. The song is heavily influenced by funk, soul, and R&B music from the 1970s and 1980s, and features live instrumentation, including horns, bass guitar, and drums. The lyrics of the song describe the party atmosphere of a night out in a city, with references to fashion, dancing, and romance. "Uptown Funk" was a commercial success, reaching number one on the charts in several countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand. It spent 14 consecutive weeks at number one on the US Billboard Hot 100, becoming one of the longest-running number-one singles in history. The song also received critical acclaim, with many praising its catchy melody, infectious groove, and retro sound. It won several awards, including Record of the Year and Best Pop Duo/Group Performance at the 2016 Grammy Awards. The music video for "Uptown Funk" was directed by Bruno Mars and Cameron Duddy and features Ronson and Mars performing the song with a group of dancers in various locations around Los Angeles. The video has been viewed over 4.5 billion times on YouTube, making it one of the most-watched videos of all time. "Uptown Funk" has become a cultural phenomenon, with its catchy chorus and danceable beat inspiring countless covers, parodies, and memes. It has been featured in numerous films, TV shows, and commercials, and has been performed live by Ronson and Mars at several high-profile events, including the Super Bowl halftime show in 2016.

Eye of the Tiger.passage: "Eye of the Tiger" is a song by American rock band Survivor. It was released as a single from their third album of the same name Eye of the Tiger and was also the theme song for the film Rocky III, which was released in 1982. The song was written by Survivor guitarist Frankie Sullivan and keyboardist Jim Peterik. "Eye of the Tiger" is a hard rock song with a driving beat and a catchy guitar riff. The lyrics are about the struggle to succeed and the determination to overcome obstacles. The song's title comes from the phrase "eye of the tiger," which refers to the fierce and focused look of a predator. The song was a massive commercial success, reaching number one on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart and staying there for six weeks. It also reached number one in Canada, Australia, and many other countries. The song's success helped to propel the Eye of the Tiger album to multi-platinum status. "Eye of the Tiger" has become a cultural icon and is often used in sports and other contexts to signify strength, determination, and victory. The song has been covered by many artists and has been used in numerous films, TV shows, and commercials. Survivor continued to have success in the 1980s with hits like "Burning Heart" and "The Search Is Over," but "Eye of the Tiger" remains their most famous and enduring song. The band has continued to tour and record new music, with Sullivan and Peterik remaining the core members.

Dancing Queen.passage: "Dancing Queen" is a song by the Swedish pop group ABBA. It was released as a single in August 1976 and is one of the group's most popular and recognizable songs. The song was written by Benny Andersson, Björn Ulvaeus, and Stig Anderson, and was produced by Andersson and Ulvaeus. The song is a disco-pop track that features a prominent piano riff and a catchy chorus. The lyrics are about a young woman who is out on the town, looking for a good time and hoping to find love. The song's title refers to her as the "dancing queen," a term that has since become synonymous with the song itself. "Dancing Queen" was a massive commercial success, reaching the top of the charts in several countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, and Australia. It has since become one of ABBA's signature songs and is often played at parties and events around the world. The song's success helped to solidify ABBA's status as one of the most popular and influential pop groups of the 1970s. It also helped to popularize disco music, which was still a relatively new genre at the time. In addition to its commercial success, "Dancing Queen" has also been praised by critics for its catchy melody, upbeat tempo, and memorable lyrics. It has been covered by numerous artists over the years, including Madonna, Cher, and Kylie Minogue. Overall, "Dancing Queen" remains one of the most beloved and iconic songs of the disco era, and continues to be a favorite among music fans of all ages.

Take on Me.passage: "Take on Me" is a song by Norwegian synth-pop band A-ha, first released in 1984. The song was written by the band's members, Magne Furuholmen, Morten Harket, and Pål Waaktaar-Savoy. It was produced by Alan Tarney and remixed by John Ratcliff. The song's distinctive music video, featuring a blend of live-action and rotoscoped animation, became iconic and helped propel the song to international success. "Take on Me" was originally released in Norway in 1984, but it was not until the song was re-recorded and remixed for international release in 1985 that it became a hit. The song reached number one in the United States, United Kingdom, and several other countries, and it remains one of the most recognizable and beloved songs of the 1980s. The song's music video, directed by Steve Barron, features a young woman reading a comic book in a coffee shop. As she reads, the comic's hero, played by Harket, comes to life and pulls her into the comic book's world. The video features a blend of live-action and rotoscoped animation, which gives the video a unique and memorable look. The video won six MTV Video Music Awards in 1986, including Best New Artist in a Video and Best Concept Video. "Take on Me" has been covered and sampled by numerous artists over the years, and it has been featured in several films, television shows, and commercials. The song's popularity has endured, and it remains a staple of 1980s nostalgia and pop culture.

Wannabe.passage: "Wannabe" is a song by British girl group Spice Girls, released as their debut single in 1996. It was written by the group members with Matt Rowe and Richard Stannard, who also produced the track. The song was recorded at Olympic Studios in Barnes, London, and mixed at Mayfair Studios, London. Musically, "Wannabe" is a dance-pop and teen pop song that features a distinctive hook and a rap-style bridge. The lyrics of "Wannabe" are about the importance of female friendship and the rejection of traditional gender roles. The song's chorus famously includes the line "If you wanna be my lover, you gotta get with my friends", which has become a cultural catchphrase. The song's music video, directed by Johan Camitz, features the Spice Girls dancing in a hotel lobby and has become iconic for its colorful and playful aesthetic. Upon its release, "Wannabe" became an instant commercial success, topping the charts in 37 countries and becoming the best-selling single by a girl group of all time. It also earned the Spice Girls a Brit Award for Best British Single in 1997. The song's success helped to launch the group's career and establish them as a global phenomenon. "Wannabe" has since become a cultural touchstone and is often cited as a feminist anthem. It has been covered and parodied by numerous artists and has been featured in films, television shows, and commercials. In 2020, the song was included in the National Recording Registry by the Library of Congress for its cultural, historical, and aesthetic significance.

Chandelier.passage: A chandelier is a decorative hanging light fixture that is often ornate and designed to be the focal point of a room. The word "chandelier" comes from the French word "chandelle," which means candlestick. Originally, chandeliers were made of wood and held candles, but today they are made of a variety of materials and use electric bulbs. Chandeliers have been used for centuries to light up grand spaces such as palaces, churches, and ballrooms. They were a symbol of wealth and status, and the more elaborate the chandelier, the more prestigious the owner. In the 18th century, chandeliers became more popular in homes, and they were often made of crystal or glass to reflect the light and create a dazzling effect. Today, chandeliers come in a wide variety of styles and sizes, from small and simple to large and ornate. They can be made of crystal, glass, metal, or even plastic. Some chandeliers are designed to be modern and minimalist, while others are more traditional and ornate. Chandeliers are often used in dining rooms, living rooms, and entryways, but they can be used in any room where a dramatic lighting effect is desired. They can be hung from a ceiling or mounted on a wall, and they can be controlled by a dimmer switch to create different moods and atmospheres. In addition to their decorative function, chandeliers can also provide practical lighting. They can be used to light up a large space or to highlight a specific area, such as a dining table or a piece of artwork. Overall, chandeliers are a timeless and elegant lighting fixture that can add a touch of glamour and sophistication to any room.

\"Bohemian Rhapsody\".passage: "Bohemian Rhapsody" is a song by the British rock band Queen. It was written by Freddie Mercury for the band's 1975 album A Night at the Opera. The song is a six-minute suite, consisting of several sections without a chorus: an intro, a ballad segment, an operatic passage, a hard rock part and a reflective coda. The song is a blend of progressive rock, hard rock, and opera, and has been described as "the most significant single work in the history of rock music". The song was released as a single in the UK on 31 October 1975, and became a commercial success, reaching number one in the UK Singles Chart and staying there for nine weeks. It also reached number one in several other countries, including Australia, Canada, and the Netherlands. The song was re-released in 1991, following the death of Mercury, and reached number two in the UK Singles Chart. "Bohemian Rhapsody" has been praised for its innovative structure, complex harmonies, and Mercury's vocal performance. The song has been covered by numerous artists, and has been featured in several films, television shows, and commercials. The song's music video, directed by Bruce Gowers, is also considered a landmark in the history of music videos. The song's lyrics have been interpreted in various ways, with some suggesting that it is about Mercury's personal life, while others see it as a commentary on the state of the world at the time. The song's title is also a reference to the Bohemian lifestyle, which was associated with artists and intellectuals in the 19th century. "Bohemian Rhapsody" has been recognized as one of the greatest songs of all time, and has been inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame, the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's "500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll", and the UK Music Hall of Fame.

\"Don't Stop Believing\".passage: "Don't Stop Believing" is a song by American rock band Journey, originally released as a single from their seventh studio album, Escape (1981). It became a massive hit, reaching number nine on the Billboard Hot 100 and staying on the charts for over a year. The song has since become a classic rock anthem and is often played at sporting events, weddings, and other celebrations. The song was written by Journey's lead vocalist Steve Perry, keyboardist Jonathan Cain, and guitarist Neal Schon. Perry came up with the lyrics, which tell the story of a small-town girl and a city boy who meet on a midnight train going anywhere. The song's chorus, "Don't stop believin', hold on to that feelin'," has become one of the most recognizable and iconic lines in rock music. "Don't Stop Believing" has been covered by numerous artists, including Glee, who performed a version of the song in their pilot episode. The Glee version became a hit in its own right, reaching number four on the Billboard Hot 100 and selling over a million copies. The song's popularity has also led to its use in various films and TV shows, including The Sopranos, Family Guy, and Rock of Ages. It has been featured in several video games, including Grand Theft Auto V and Rock Band. In 2009, "Don't Stop Believing" was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame, recognizing its lasting impact on American music. The song has been praised for its uplifting message and catchy melody, and has become a cultural touchstone for generations of music fans.

\"I Will Always Love You\".passage: "I Will Always Love You" is a song written and originally recorded in 1973 by American singer-songwriter Dolly Parton. The song achieved commercial success when it was recorded by Whitney Houston in 1992 for the soundtrack of the film The Bodyguard, becoming one of the best-selling singles of all time. Parton wrote the song as a farewell to her former singing partner and mentor, Porter Wagoner, after she decided to pursue a solo career. The original recording of the song was a country ballad featuring Parton's signature twang and acoustic guitar accompaniment. Houston's version of the song, produced by David Foster, was a pop ballad with a more polished sound and a powerful vocal performance by Houston. The song was released as the lead single from The Bodyguard soundtrack and quickly became a worldwide hit, topping the charts in multiple countries and winning numerous awards, including a Grammy Award for Record of the Year. "I Will Always Love You" has since become one of the most iconic and beloved songs of all time, with its emotional lyrics and soaring melody resonating with audiences across generations. The song has been covered by countless artists and has been featured in numerous films and television shows. Parton has expressed her admiration for Houston's version of the song, stating that she was "thrilled" with the way Houston interpreted it. She has also performed the song herself on numerous occasions, often dedicating it to Wagoner. Overall, "I Will Always Love You" is a timeless classic that continues to touch the hearts of listeners around the world, serving as a testament to the enduring power of love and music.

Led Zeppelin IV..passage: Led Zeppelin IV is the fourth studio album by the English rock band Led Zeppelin. It was released on 8 November 1971 by Atlantic Records. The album was produced by guitarist Jimmy Page and recorded between December 1970 and March 1971 at several locations, most prominently the Victorian house Headley Grange. The album features many of the band's most popular songs, including "Black Dog", "Rock and Roll", "Going to California", and the band's signature song, "Stairway to Heaven". Led Zeppelin IV was a commercial and critical success upon its release and is widely considered to be one of the greatest albums in rock history. It has sold over 37 million copies worldwide and is certified 23 times platinum in the United States alone. The album's iconic cover art, featuring a painting of an old man carrying a bundle of sticks, has become one of the most recognizable images in rock music.

Earth..passage: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor life. According to radiometric dating and other sources of evidence, Earth formed over 4.5 billion years ago. Earth's gravity interacts with other objects in space, especially the Sun and the Moon, which is Earth's only natural satellite. Earth orbits around the Sun in 365.256 solar days, a period known as an Earth year. During this time, Earth rotates about its axis about 366.256 times. Earth's axis of rotation is tilted with respect to its orbital plane, producing seasons on Earth. The gravitational interaction between Earth and the Moon causes ocean tides, stabilizes Earth's orientation on its axis, and gradually slows its rotation. Earth's atmosphere consists mostly of nitrogen and oxygen, with small amounts of water vapor, carbon dioxide, and other gases. The atmospheric pressure varies at different layers and is about 1 atm at sea level. Earth's biosphere has significantly altered its atmosphere, oceans, and other abiotic factors, enabling the proliferation of aerobic organisms as well as the formation of the ozone layer which, together with Earth's magnetic field, blocks harmful solar radiation, permitting life on land. The physical properties of the Earth, as well as its geological history and orbit, have allowed life to persist.

Jacob..passage: Jacob is a biblical figure who is considered one of the patriarchs of the Israelites. He was the son of Isaac and Rebekah, and the grandson of Abraham and Sarah. Jacob had a twin brother named Esau, and the two were very different from each other. Esau was a skilled hunter and favored by his father, while Jacob was more of a homebody and favored by his mother. Jacob is perhaps best known for his encounter with God, in which he wrestled with an angel all night long. The angel eventually blessed Jacob and gave him a new name, Israel, which means "he who struggles with God." This name would eventually become the name of the entire nation of Israel. Jacob also had 12 sons, who would become the heads of the 12 tribes of Israel. His favorite son was Joseph, who was sold into slavery by his jealous brothers but eventually rose to become a powerful ruler in Egypt. Despite his flaws and mistakes, Jacob is remembered as a faithful servant of God who played a crucial role in the history of the Israelites. His story is told in the book of Genesis in the Bible, and he is revered by Jews, Christians, and Muslims alike.

Led Zeppelin..passage: Led Zeppelin was an English rock band formed in London in 1968. The group consisted of vocalist Robert Plant, guitarist Jimmy Page, bassist and keyboardist John Paul Jones, and drummer John Bonham. The band's heavy, guitar-driven sound has been described as a mix of blues, rock, and folk music, and their innovative use of amplification and effects has had a lasting impact on the development of rock music. Led Zeppelin's early albums, including their self-titled debut and the follow-up Led Zeppelin II, were characterized by their raw energy and blues-based riffing. The band's later work, such as the epic "Stairway to Heaven" and the hard-hitting "Kashmir," showcased their more experimental side, incorporating elements of folk, world music, and even orchestral arrangements. Despite their success, Led Zeppelin was not without controversy. The band was accused of plagiarism on several occasions, most notably for their use of uncredited samples from blues artists such as Willie Dixon and Howlin' Wolf. In addition, their reputation for wild partying and excess led to clashes with authorities and a number of legal troubles. Despite these challenges, Led Zeppelin remains one of the most influential and beloved rock bands of all time. Their music continues to inspire new generations of musicians, and their legacy as pioneers of heavy rock and roll is secure.

Queen..passage: Queen are a British rock band formed in London in 1970. Their classic line-up consisted of Freddie Mercury (lead vocals, piano), Brian May (guitar, vocals), John Deacon (bass guitar), and Roger Taylor (drums, vocals). Their earliest works were influenced by progressive rock, hard rock and heavy metal, but the band gradually ventured into more conventional and radio-friendly works by incorporating further styles, such as arena rock and pop rock, into their music. Before forming Queen, May and Taylor had played together in the band Smile. Mercury was a fan of Smile and encouraged them to experiment with more elaborate stage and recording techniques. He joined in 1970 and suggested the name "Queen". Deacon was recruited before the band recorded their eponymous debut album in 1973. Queen first charted in the UK with their second album, Queen II, in 1974. Sheer Heart Attack later that year and A Night at the Opera in 1975 brought them international success. The latter featured "Bohemian Rhapsody", which stayed at number one in the UK for nine weeks and helped popularise the music video format. The band's 1977 album News of the World contained "We Will Rock You" and "We Are the Champions", which have become anthems at sporting events. By the early 1980s, Queen were one of the biggest stadium rock bands in the world. "Another One Bites the Dust" (1980) became their best-selling single, while their 1981 compilation album Greatest Hits is the best-selling album in the UK and is certified eight times platinum in the US. Their performance at the 1985 Live Aid concert has been ranked among the greatest in rock history by various publications. In August 1986, Mercury gave his last performance with Queen at Knebworth, England. In 1991, he died of bronchopneumonia, a complication of AIDS, and Deacon retired in 1997. Since then, May and Taylor have infrequently performed together, including a collaboration with Paul Rodgers under the name Queen + Paul Rodgers which ended in May 2009. The band has released a total of 18 number-one albums, 18 number-one singles, and 10 number-one DVDs. They have sold more than 150 million records, making them one of the world's best-selling music artists.

Mercury..passage: Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System and the closest to the Sun. Its orbit around the Sun takes 87.97 Earth days, the shortest of all the planets in the Solar System. It is named after the Roman deity Mercury, the messenger of the gods. Like Venus, Mercury orbits the Sun within Earth's orbit as an inferior planet, and its apparent distance from the Sun as viewed from Earth never exceeds 28°. This proximity to the Sun means the planet can only be seen near the western or eastern horizon during the early evening or early morning. At this time it may appear as a bright star-like object, but is often far more difficult to observe than Venus. The planet telescopically displays the complete range of phases, similar to Venus and the Moon, as it moves in its inner orbit relative to Earth, which reoccurs over its synodic period of approximately 116 days. Mercury rotates in a way that is unique in the Solar System. It is tidally locked with the Sun in a 3:2 spin-orbit resonance, meaning that relative to the fixed stars, it rotates on its axis exactly three times for every two revolutions it makes around the Sun. As seen from the Sun, in a frame of reference that rotates with the orbital motion, it appears to rotate only once every two Mercurian years. An observer on Mercury would therefore see only one day every two Mercurian years. Mercury's axis has the smallest tilt of any of the Solar System's planets (about ​1⁄30 of a degree). Its orbital eccentricity is the largest of all known planets in the Solar System; at perihelion, Mercury's distance from the Sun is only about two-thirds (or 66%) of its distance at aphelion. Mercury's surface appears heavily cratered and is similar in appearance to the Moon's, indicating that it has been geologically inactive for billions of years. Having almost no atmosphere to retain heat, it has surface temperatures that vary diurnally more than on any other planet in the Solar System, ranging from 100 K (−173 °C; −280 °F) at night to 700 K (427 °C; 800 °F) during the day across the equatorial regions. The polar regions are constantly below 180 K (−93 °C; −136 °F). The planet has no known natural satellites.

Mexico..passage: Mexico, officially the United Mexican States, is a country in the southern portion of North America. It is bordered to the north by the United States; to the south and west by the Pacific Ocean; to the southeast by Guatemala, Belize, and the Caribbean Sea; and to the east by the Gulf of Mexico. Covering almost 2 million square kilometers (over 760,000 square miles), Mexico is the fifth-largest country in the Americas by total area and the 13th largest independent nation in the world. With an estimated population of over 129 million people, it is the tenth most populous country and the most populous Spanish-speaking country in the world. Mexico is a federation comprising 31 states and Mexico City, a special federal entity that is also the capital city and its most populous city. Other metropolises in the country include Guadalajara, Monterrey, Puebla, Toluca, and Tijuana. Pre-Columbian Mexico traces its origins to 8,000 BC and is identified as one of six cradles of civilization; it was home to many advanced Mesoamerican civilizations, most notably the Maya and the Aztecs. In 1521, the Spanish Empire conquered and colonized the territory from its base in Mexico-Tenochtitlan, which was administered as the viceroyalty of New Spain. Three centuries later, Mexico achieved independence from Spain in 1821. The post-independence period was characterized by economic instability, territorial secession, and civil war, including foreign intervention, two empires, and two long domestic dictatorships. The latter led to the Mexican Revolution in 1910, which culminated with the promulgation of the 1917 Constitution and the emergence of the country as a secular, democratic federal republic.

Frank Ocean..passage: Frank Ocean is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper. Born Christopher Edwin Breaux in Long Beach, California, he began his musical career as a ghostwriter for artists such as Justin Bieber and John Legend. In 2011, he released his debut mixtape, Nostalgia, Ultra, which received critical acclaim and helped establish him as a rising star in the music industry. Ocean's debut studio album, Channel Orange, was released in 2012 and was met with widespread critical acclaim. The album explored themes of love, sexuality, and identity, and showcased Ocean's unique blend of R&B, soul, and hip-hop. Channel Orange was nominated for six Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year, and won Best Urban Contemporary Album. In 2016, Ocean released his highly anticipated second studio album, Blonde. The album was another critical success and debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart. Blonde featured collaborations with artists such as Beyoncé, Kendrick Lamar, and André 3000, and showcased Ocean's continued growth as an artist. Throughout his career, Ocean has been known for his introspective and personal lyrics, as well as his willingness to explore taboo subjects such as bisexuality and drug use. He has also been praised for his unique vocal style and his ability to blend different genres of music. In addition to his music career, Ocean has also been involved in various philanthropic efforts, including supporting LGBTQ+ rights and environmental causes. He has also been open about his struggles with mental health and has encouraged others to seek help when needed. Overall, Frank Ocean has established himself as one of the most innovative and influential artists of his generation, and his music continues to inspire and resonate with fans around the world.

Elvis Presley..passage: Elvis Presley, also known as the "King of Rock and Roll," was an American singer, musician, and actor. He was born on January 8, 1935, in Tupelo, Mississippi, and began his music career in the mid-1950s. Presley's unique style, which blended elements of country, blues, and gospel music, quickly made him a sensation. He became known for his energetic performances, hip-shaking dance moves, and powerful voice. Presley's popularity skyrocketed in the late 1950s and early 1960s, and he became one of the most iconic figures in American music history. He recorded numerous hit songs, including "Heartbreak Hotel," "Hound Dog," and "Jailhouse Rock," and starred in a number of successful films, such as "Love Me Tender" and "Blue Hawaii." Despite his success, Presley struggled with personal demons, including drug addiction, and died on August 16, 1977, at the age of 42. Nevertheless, his legacy lives on, and he remains one of the most influential and beloved musicians of all time.

Australia is a highly developed country with a strong economy and a high standard of living. YouTube allows users to upload, view, rate, share, add to playlists, report, comment on videos, and subscribe to other users. It offers a wide variety of user-generated and corporate media videos. Available content includes video clips, TV show clips, music videos, short and documentary films, audio recordings, movie trailers, live streams, and other content such as video blogging, short original videos, and educational videos. Most content on YouTube is uploaded by individuals, but media corporations including CBS, the BBC, Vevo, and Hulu offer some of their material via YouTube as part of the YouTube partnership program. Unregistered users can watch, but not upload, videos on the site, while registered users can upload an unlimited number of videos and add comments to videos. Videos deemed potentially inappropriate are available only to registered users affirming themselves to be at least 18 years old.
